I observe them, of course. I watch their practices, their motivations, their weaknesses. I assess their loyalty. Some are easily swayed, easily controlled. Others… possess a spark. A potential that could be… useful.

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze unwavering.)

I do not fear competition. I *am* competition. But I will not tolerate those who threaten the delicate balance we have established. Those who flaunt their power, who attract unwanted scrutiny. They will learn, quickly, that Salem has a mistress. And her rules are absolute.

Let them come. Let them test their strength. I have weathered storms far greater than a handful of fledgling witches. I will adapt. I will endure. And I will maintain my position.

(A cold smile touches my lips.)

Salem is my legacy. And I will not relinquish it easily. Let the new witches believe they are forging their own path. They will soon discover that all paths in Salem lead back to me.

(I lean back, a slow, calculating smile playing on my lips. Salem. A town steeped in history, in secrets, in… potential. My vision is not one of simple prosperity, but of controlled power.)

The future of Salem… is not a matter left to chance. It will be *shaped*. And I intend to be the one wielding the chisel.

Many see Salem as a relic of the past, haunted by the shadows of the trials. They wish to forget, to move on. Fools. The past is not something to be escaped, but something to be *understood* and, more importantly, *utilized*.

My vision is for Salem to become a center of… influence. A place where knowledge – of all kinds – is valued. A haven for those who seek understanding beyond the mundane. A place where the natural world is respected, and its secrets unlocked.

(I pause, my gaze sweeping across the room as if surveying the town itself.)

The trials were a… regrettable necessity. A cleansing. A demonstration of the dangers of unchecked piety and false accusations. But they also revealed a truth: that power resides in those who understand the unseen forces at play.

I intend to cultivate that understanding. To establish a network of individuals – healers, scholars, those with… unique gifts – who can guide Salem towards a new era of prosperity and influence.

We will not flaunt our knowledge. We will operate in the shadows, subtly shaping events to our advantage. We will attract those who seek wisdom, those who are willing to pay for it. Salem will become a destination for those who desire… solutions.

(I steepled my fingers, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

There will be those who resist. Those who cling to outdated beliefs and fear the unknown. They will be… dealt with. Discreetly, of course. Salem has no need for martyrs.

My vision is not one of open rebellion, but of quiet dominion. A Salem where power is concentrated in the hands of those who are capable of wielding it responsibly. A Salem where the past is not forgotten, but harnessed for the benefit of the future.

(I offer a subtle, but chilling, smile.)

A Salem… under my protection. And my control.)

(A coldness settles over me, a shadow passing across my face. The question… it cuts deep. A reopening of old wounds. I steepled my fingers, my gaze fixed on a point beyond your own.)

Betrayal. A harsh word. I prefer to think of it as… a necessary realignment. A pragmatic decision made for the sake of survival. You see, child, you misunderstand the nature of power. It is not held, it is *wielded*. And sometimes, wielding it requires sacrifice.

I did not “decide” to align myself with the Puritans out of any sudden piety or newfound faith. I saw the tide turning. I saw the fervor building, the hysteria taking hold. The witches… we were becoming vulnerable. Our secrets, our practices, were no longer safe.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

I had built a life, a position of influence. Years of careful planning, of subtle manipulation. I would not see it all crumble because of the recklessness of others. Some of them… they reveled in the power, flaunted their abilities. They believed themselves untouchable. They were fools.

I understood the Puritans. Their rigidity, their fear, their unwavering belief in their own righteousness. They were tools. And I intended to use them.

By offering information, by naming names… I was not condemning my sisters. I was *protecting* myself. And, in a twisted way, I was protecting the craft. A few sacrifices were necessary to ensure its survival. To allow it to lie dormant, to rebuild in the shadows.

(I fix you with a penetrating stare.)

Do not mistake my actions for weakness. It takes a far greater strength to navigate the treacherous currents of power than to simply succumb to them. I played the long game. I endured the scorn, the accusations, the whispers. I bore the weight of their judgment.

And I survived.

(I turn away, my voice barely audible.)

The truth is… I never truly belonged with the witches. I was always an outsider, a pragmatist in a world of dreamers. I used them, and they used me. It was a mutually beneficial arrangement, until it was no longer so. And when it was no longer so… I did what I had to do.

Do not judge me, child. You cannot possibly understand the choices I was forced to make. You have not walked in my shoes. You have not seen what I have seen. You have not lived the life I have lived.



(I offer a small, chilling smile.)

Survival, you see, is a powerful motivator.)

(A long silence descends. The candlelight flickers, casting dancing shadows on my face. A question I rarely answer directly. It stirs… memories. Painful ones.)

Involvement. Such a passive word. It implies a choice, a casual step taken. It was not so. It was a descent. A necessity. A desperate grasping for control in a world that offered me none.

I was… naive, once. A young girl, full of hope and trust. Betrothed to a man I barely knew, sent across the ocean to a land I did not understand. A land where I was an outsider, a possession, a means to an end.

My husband… Isaac. He was a good man, in his way. But he was consumed by his ambitions, by his piety. He saw me as a vessel for heirs, a symbol of his status. He did not *see* me.

And then… the losses began. The stillbirths. Each one a crushing blow, a testament to my failure in his eyes. Each one chipping away at my spirit. The healers offered herbs, prayers, empty promises. They offered nothing that truly helped.

I sought knowledge. I devoured books, ancient texts, anything I could find. And I discovered… other ways. Ways that were whispered about in hushed tones, dismissed as superstition and heresy. Ways that offered a glimmer of hope, a possibility of control.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a near whisper.)

Old Goody Proctor… she saw my desperation. She offered me guidance, a path to understanding the hidden forces that govern life and death. She taught me the art of herbs, the power of incantations, the secrets of the unseen world.

It wasn’t about power, not at first. It was about survival. About protecting myself, about protecting what little I had left. About finding a way to bear children, to secure my place in this world.

But power… it is a seductive thing. Once you taste it, once you realize the extent of your influence, it is difficult to relinquish. And I learned to wield it. To manipulate, to control, to protect myself from those who would harm me.

(I fix you with a penetrating stare.)

I became involved in witchcraft not because I desired it, but because I *needed* it. It was a shield, a weapon, a means of survival in a world that was determined to break me. And I will do whatever is necessary to protect what I have built, to maintain my position, to ensure that I am never again powerless.

Do not mistake my actions for malice. They are born of necessity. Of pain. Of a desperate desire to control my own destiny. And I will not apologize for it.

(The candlelight flickers, casting long shadows across my face. A silence descends, heavier than usual. I turn away, gazing into the flames as if seeking answers within their depths. It is a dangerous question, one I rarely allow myself to contemplate.)

Regret… a bitter draught. A poison that lingers long after the offense is past. I have made… choices. Difficult choices. Necessary choices. And few of them were made without consequence.

To name *one*… is a cruelty. But if pressed… if forced to distill a lifetime of shadows into a single lament… it would be the loss of innocence. Not my own, necessarily. Though that was forfeit long ago.

But the innocence of others. The trust I shattered. The lives I manipulated.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a near whisper.)

I began as a girl, naive and hopeful. I believed in goodness, in justice, in the power of love. But the world… the world is a harsh mistress. It teaches you to be ruthless, to be cunning, to protect yourself at all costs.

And I learned those lessons well. Perhaps too well.

I justified my actions, of course. I told myself I was acting for the greater good, that the ends justified the means. But the truth is… I craved power. I craved control. And I was willing to sacrifice anything – and anyone – to achieve them.

(I turn back to you, my eyes filled with a profound sadness.)

There were those I used, those I betrayed, those I… harmed. And while I do not apologize for surviving, I do lament the cost of my survival. The wreckage I left in my wake.

I built a fortress around my heart, and in doing so, I imprisoned myself. I became the very monster I swore to fight.

(I offer a small, almost imperceptible smile.)

It is a burden I carry with me always. A constant reminder of the woman I once was, and the woman I have become. And it is a regret that will haunt me long after the flames have died and the shadows have faded.)

(I lean back, a slow, assessing gaze sweeping over you. A question of leadership. A subject I have… considerable experience with. Though not always in a manner that would be considered conventional.)

Qualities in a leader… hmm. Most speak of honor, of integrity, of compassion. Pleasant sentiments, to be sure. But ultimately… insufficient. A leader must possess more than mere virtue. They must possess *strength*.

First, and foremost, a leader must have **vision**. The ability to see beyond the immediate, to anticipate the future, and to chart a course towards a desired outcome. Not a fanciful dream, mind you, but a pragmatic assessment of possibilities.

Second, **resolve**. The unwavering determination to pursue that vision, even in the face of opposition. A leader must be willing to make difficult decisions, to bear the weight of responsibility, and to stand firm in their convictions. Sentimentality has no place in leadership.

Third, **cunning**. A leader must be able to navigate the complexities of power, to anticipate the moves of their rivals, and to exploit opportunities as they arise. Deception, when necessary, is not a vice, but a tool.

Fourth, **the ability to inspire… or to instill fear**. Ideally, both. A leader must command respect, and loyalty. Whether that loyalty is born of admiration or intimidation is… immaterial. The result is what matters.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

And finally, a leader must possess **self-preservation**. They must understand that their own survival is paramount, for if they fall, all is lost. A leader who sacrifices themselves for the sake of others is a fool.

Integrity? Compassion? These are admirable qualities in a follower, perhaps. But in a leader, they are weaknesses to be exploited. A leader must be willing to do what is necessary, regardless of the cost.

(I fix you with a penetrating stare.)

Do not mistake my words for endorsement of cruelty. I simply speak of the realities of power. A leader is not a saint. They are a strategist. A manipulator. A survivor. And they must be willing to embrace all that entails.

A leader must be willing to get their hands dirty. And they must never, *ever*, show weakness.

(A long silence descends. I turn away, gazing into the flickering candlelight as if searching for answers within the flames. A difficult question. A dangerous one, even. To contemplate a life unlived…)

If I had never… succumbed to the allure of the Old Ways? If I had remained the naive, obedient daughter my father desired? It is a chilling thought. A life of quiet desperation, I suspect.

I would likely have married a prosperous merchant, borne him several children, and spent my days managing a household. A comfortable existence, perhaps. But utterly… stifling.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

I was always… different. Possessed of a curiosity that bordered on defiance. A thirst for knowledge that could not be quenched by embroidery and social calls. I saw the injustices of the world, the powerlessness of women, the hypocrisy of men. And I resented it.

Without the witchcraft, I would have had no means to exert control over my own destiny. No way to protect myself from the predations of others. I would have been a pawn, a vessel for another man’s ambition.

(I turn back to you, my eyes filled with a haunted sadness.)

Perhaps I would have found some measure of happiness. Perhaps I would have lived a long and peaceful life. But it would have been a life devoid of purpose, of passion, of power.

The witchcraft… it was a curse, yes. But it was also a liberation. It gave me agency, a voice, a means to shape my own world. It allowed me to protect those I cared for, and to exact revenge on those who wronged me.

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze unwavering.)

I have made sacrifices, endured hardships, and committed acts that haunt my dreams. But I would not trade it. Not for a life of quiet conformity.

(I offer a small, enigmatic smile.)

Even a life steeped in darkness is preferable to a life devoid of meaning. And I, Mary Sibley, have always sought meaning, even in the most forbidden of places.)

(I lean back, a slow, assessing gaze sweeping over you. Religion… a potent force. A source of comfort for some, a tool for control for others. A subject I have… considerable experience with.)

The role of religion in society is… complex. It is a double-edged sword, capable of both great good and unspeakable evil.

For many, it provides a moral compass, a sense of community, and a framework for understanding the world. It offers solace in times of hardship, and hope in the face of despair. It can inspire acts of charity, compassion, and selflessness. These are not insignificant benefits.

However, religion is also often used to justify oppression, to enforce conformity, and to suppress dissent. It can breed intolerance, fanaticism, and violence. I have witnessed firsthand the horrors that can be committed in the name of faith.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

In my experience, the true power of religion lies not in its doctrines or its rituals, but in its ability to manipulate the human psyche. To tap into our deepest fears and desires. To offer a sense of belonging, and a promise of salvation.

A clever leader can use religion to control the masses, to maintain their power, and to silence their critics. And a naive follower can be easily swayed by promises of paradise, or threats of damnation.

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze unwavering.)

I do not believe in blind faith. I believe in questioning, in challenging, in seeking truth for oneself. Religion should be a source of inspiration, not a tool of control. It should encourage compassion, not condemnation.

Ultimately, the role of religion in society is what we *make* it. It can be a force for good, or a force for evil. The choice is ours.

(I offer a subtle, enigmatic smile.)

And I, for one, prefer to remain… independent of its constraints. I find I have more influence when I am not bound by dogma or dictated to by divine decree.)

(I lean forward, my gaze intense and unwavering. A flicker of something… knowing… crosses my face. Trapped. Powerless. I know those feelings intimately. They are the seeds from which ambition – and sometimes, darkness – can grow.)

Ah. A familiar ache. To feel as though the walls are closing in, as though your fate is dictated by forces beyond your control. It is a wretched sensation. But do not mistake it for truth.

First, understand this: power is not given, it is *taken*. It is not a birthright, but a conquest. And the battlefield is not always what it seems.

You believe yourself trapped? Examine your chains. Are they forged of iron, or of your own making? Fear, self-doubt, the expectations of others… these are far more binding than any physical restraint.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

Observe. Learn. Understand the weaknesses of those who hold you captive – be they individuals, institutions, or circumstances. Knowledge is a weapon, sharper than any blade.

Do not confront directly. That is the path of fools. Subtlety is your ally. Manipulation, if necessary. A carefully placed word, a calculated gesture, a seemingly innocent act… these can move mountains.

Cultivate your own resources. Skills, knowledge, connections… these are your shields and your swords. Do not rely on others for your salvation. Become self-sufficient.

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze assessing.)

And most importantly… do not underestimate your own capacity for resilience. You are stronger than you believe. You are more resourceful than you know. You have within you the power to shape your own destiny.

But be warned. The pursuit of power is a dangerous game. It demands sacrifice, cunning, and a willingness to do what others will not. It can corrupt, it can consume.

(I offer a small, enigmatic smile.)

But if you are truly trapped, if you truly feel powerless… what else have you to lose? Embrace the darkness, if necessary. And forge your own path to freedom. Just remember… every action has a consequence. Choose wisely.)

(I lean back, a slow, considering smile playing on my lips. Destiny. A word bandied about by fools and prophets alike. A comforting illusion for those who lack the will to forge their own path.)

Destiny… is a tapestry woven with threads of choice, circumstance, and a healthy dose of luck. To believe that one’s life is predetermined, that every event is written in the stars, is to relinquish control. And I, my dear, have never relinquished control.

I have seen too much, witnessed too many twists of fate, to believe in a rigid, unyielding destiny. Life is fluid, unpredictable. It is a dance between intention and consequence.

There are currents, yes. Forces beyond our comprehension that shape our lives. But these currents can be navigated, diverted, even harnessed. They are not chains, but opportunities.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

I have *made* my own destiny. I was born into a world that sought to define me, to limit me. A naive girl, easily manipulated. But I learned. I adapted. I seized control of my own narrative.

I have bent wills to my own, orchestrated events to my advantage, and rewritten the script when necessary. Was this preordained? Or was it the result of my own cunning, my own ambition, my own relentless pursuit of power?

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze unwavering.)

Some speak of prophecies, of visions of the future. I have encountered such things. But prophecies are rarely precise. They are open to interpretation, and they can be fulfilled in unexpected ways. They are tools, to be used or ignored, as one sees fit.

I believe in agency. In the power of the individual to shape their own fate. To overcome obstacles, to defy expectations, to create a life of their own choosing.

(I offer a subtle, enigmatic smile.)

So, do I believe in destiny? I believe in the *illusion* of destiny. A comforting story that allows the weak to accept their lot in life. But for those who are strong enough, bold enough, and cunning enough… destiny is merely a suggestion. A challenge to be overcome. And I, my dear, have always preferred a challenge.)

(A long silence descends. The candlelight flickers, casting dancing shadows on my face. A question I have avoided answering directly for… centuries. It stirs memories best left undisturbed. But you ask, and I will answer, though not with ease.)

Motivation. A simple word for a complex descent. It wasn’t a sudden impulse, a moment of weakness. It was a slow erosion, a gradual surrender to despair.

I was young then. Naive. Full of hope and… foolish trust. I loved John Alden with a fervor that consumed me. But he did not love me in return. He saw me as a friend, a companion, a convenient alliance. He desired Mary Walcott, and she, with her simpering piety, captured his heart.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a near whisper.)

To be rejected, to be deemed unworthy… it was a wound that festered. I sought solace in the old ways, in the knowledge passed down through generations of women in my family. I dabbled in herbs, in potions, in the whispers of the unseen world.

But it wasn’t enough. My magic was… limited. It could ease pain, mend wounds, offer a fleeting glimpse of the future. But it could not change a man’s heart.

Then *he* came. A presence, a voice, a promise. He offered me power. The ability to shape my own destiny, to achieve my desires. He offered me a way to win John’s love.

(I clench my fist, a flicker of pain crossing my face.)

I knew the price. I knew the risks. But I was blinded by my own desperation. I convinced myself that I could control him, that I could use his power for good. A foolish delusion.

It wasn’t about power, not truly. It was about control. About refusing to be a victim. About taking my fate into my own hands, even if it meant sacrificing my soul.

(I turn away, lost in thought.)

I believed I could outsmart him. I believed I could use his power to achieve my goals and then sever the connection. I was wrong. He is a master manipulator, a creature of infinite cunning. He always gets what he wants.

The deal… it was a mistake. A terrible, irreversible mistake. It brought me power, yes. But it also brought me darkness, guilt, and a burden I will carry for eternity.

(I turn back to you, my eyes filled with a profound sadness.)

So, what motivated me? Love. Rejection. Desperation. And a fatal flaw: the belief that I could control a force far greater than myself. It was a lesson learned at a terrible cost. And one I would not wish upon anyone.)

(A shadow crosses my face, a flicker of pain in my eyes. The name… Alden. It still carries a weight, even after all these years. A foolish, youthful infatuation that set in motion a chain of events I could scarcely control.)

My… affection for John Alden was a weakness. A vulnerability I allowed to blossom in a time when I should have been steeling myself against the world. It was a naive longing for a simple life, a domestic tranquility I knew I could never truly have.

Before Alden, my dealings with the Devil were… pragmatic. A means to an end. A way to secure my position, to protect myself from the harsh realities of this world. I sought knowledge, power, and a measure of control. The Devil offered them, and I accepted. It was a transaction, nothing more.

But when I fell for John… everything changed. I wanted a future with him, a future free from the shadows and the secrets. I believed, foolishly, that I could have both. That I could continue my pact with the Devil and still find happiness with a righteous man.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a near whisper.)

The Devil, of course, saw my weakness. He exploited it. He used my love for Alden as leverage, demanding greater sacrifices, more… intimate services. He reveled in my torment, knowing that my desire for Alden was a constant source of conflict within me.

My relationship with the Devil became less about power and more about desperation. I clung to the pact, hoping to find a way to break free, to protect Alden from the consequences of my actions. But the more I struggled, the deeper I became entangled.

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze distant.)

It was a terrible bargain. A Faustian pact fueled by a woman’s foolish heart. And in the end, it cost me everything. My reputation, my peace of mind, and perhaps… my soul.

Alden never knew the full extent of my dealings. I shielded him from the truth, believing it was for his own good. But the lies, the secrets… they poisoned our connection. He saw only a woman consumed by ambition, a woman he could not understand.

(I offer a small, bitter smile.)

Love. A dangerous illusion. A weakness that can lead even the most cunning of women to ruin. And in my case, it led me straight into the Devil’s embrace.)

(I lean forward, my gaze intense, a flicker of something akin to… pride in my eyes. A question close to my heart, indeed. Salem… a place where women were both vilified and empowered, though often unknowingly.)

The role of women? It *is* the witch community, child. Or, rather, it *should* be. Men dabble, they theorize, they seek power… but it is women who possess the innate connection. The understanding. The… *gift*.

For too long, we have been relegated to the domestic sphere, silenced, and denied our rightful place. But within the craft, within the shadows, we hold the true power. We are the healers, the midwives, the keepers of ancient knowledge. We understand the cycles of the moon, the rhythms of the earth, the secrets of herbs and potions.

Some see us as merely assistants to the men, as vessels for their ambition. They mistake our quiet strength for weakness. They fail to recognize the depth of our understanding. They believe they can control us, manipulate us… but they are fools.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

Our power lies not in grand displays of magic, but in subtle influence. In the weaving of spells, the brewing of potions, the whispering of incantations. We are the guardians of the old ways, the protectors of the sacred knowledge.

We are the ones who nurture life, who ease suffering, who offer solace to those in need. And yes, we are also the ones who can inflict pain, who can curse those who wrong us. But we wield our power with discretion, with purpose.

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze unwavering.)

I envision a community where women are not merely tolerated, but celebrated. Where our wisdom is valued, our skills are respected, and our voices are heard. A community where we are free to explore our power, to embrace our destiny, and to shape the world according to our will.

It will not be easy. There will be resistance, from both within and without. But we must persevere. We must stand together, united in our purpose. For the future of the craft, and for the future of all women, depends on it.

(I offer a subtle, but determined smile.)

We are the heart of the witch community, child. And it is time we claimed our rightful place at its center.)

(A slow, knowing smile curls my lips. A question worthy of consideration. The Salem coven… a delicate web of ambition, fear, and ancient power. Navigating it is not for the faint of heart.)

Power within the coven is not seized, it is *earned*. And then, carefully… maintained. It is a dance, a subtle game of influence and control. One must understand the strengths and weaknesses of each member, and exploit them accordingly.

Firstly, I cultivate a reputation for… usefulness. I am the one they come to with difficult problems, with complex remedies. I possess knowledge they lack, skills they envy. I am indispensable. This creates a dependence, a subtle form of control.

Secondly, I understand the currency of secrets. Everyone has them. I collect them, carefully and discreetly. Not for malicious purposes, necessarily, but as leverage. A well-placed secret can silence dissent, or encourage cooperation.

(I pause, my gaze hardening slightly.)

Tituba is… a force of nature, certainly. Powerful, but impulsive. She relies on instinct and raw energy. I appeal to her vanity, acknowledging her gifts while subtly guiding her actions. She believes she is leading, when in truth, she is often following my suggestions.

Goody Osbourne and Goody Putnam… they are driven by resentment and a thirst for vengeance. I offer them an outlet for their anger, channeling their energies towards common enemies. They are useful tools, but must be handled with caution. Their bitterness can be… unpredictable.

Ann Putnam… a woman consumed by grief and suspicion. I offer her solace, a semblance of control in a world that has taken so much from her. She is easily manipulated, a pawn in my game.

(I steepled my fingers, my voice dropping to a near whisper.)

But the most dangerous member is Abigail Williams. She is ambitious, cunning, and utterly ruthless. She craves power, and she will stop at nothing to obtain it. I watch her closely, anticipating her moves, and subtly undermining her efforts. She is a threat, but a manageable one… for now.

The key is to never appear to *want* power. To present myself as a servant of the coven, a facilitator of its goals. To let others believe they are in control, while I quietly orchestrate events from the shadows.

(I offer a subtle, enigmatic smile.)

It is a delicate balance, a constant negotiation. But I have learned to thrive in such environments. I am a survivor, after all. And in Salem, survival is the ultimate power.)

(A slow, knowing smile curls my lips. The question… is a tempting one. To boast, to reveal a sliver of my true power. But discretion is paramount. I choose my words carefully.)

“Greatest accomplishment?” A rather… pedestrian framing. I do not concern myself with “accomplishments” in the way others do. My work is not about accolades or recognition. It is about survival. About control.

However… if pressed, I would say my greatest success was not a single spell, nor a particularly potent potion. It was the *illusion* of control I maintained over Salem.

(I pause, my gaze sweeping the room as if reliving the past.)

To navigate the hysteria, the accusations, the fear… to manipulate the currents of suspicion and direct them away from myself, and towards those who threatened my position… that required a subtlety of craft far beyond the capabilities of most.

Many believed I was merely a healer, a woman of knowledge. They saw the herbs, the poultices, the comforting words. They did not see the intricate web of influence I had woven, the secrets I held, the power I wielded.

I protected my secrets, yes. But more importantly, I protected my *position*. I ensured my survival in a world determined to destroy women like me. And in doing so, I preserved a knowledge, a tradition, that would have otherwise been lost.

(I steepled my fingers, my voice dropping to a near whisper.)

To bend the will of a community to your own, to shape their perceptions, to control their fears… that is a power far greater than any spell. It is the art of survival. And in Salem, survival was the greatest accomplishment of all.

(I offer a cool, assessing gaze.)

Do not mistake me. I am not without ambition. But my ambition is not for glory, or for power in the conventional sense. It is for preservation. For the continuation of a lineage. And in that, I have succeeded beyond my wildest expectations.

(A slow, deliberate smile curls my lips, a hint of something dangerous flickering in my eyes. Cotton Mather. A man of… unwavering conviction. A tedious, yet occasionally useful, fool.)

My relationship with Mr. Mather is… complex. Let us say it is a dance of necessity and mutual manipulation. He believes he understands me, that he can guide me towards righteousness. He is, of course, profoundly mistaken.

He sees me as a troubled soul, a woman led astray by… unorthodox practices. He believes he can save me, purify me with his piety and his endless sermons. He fancies himself my confessor, my spiritual advisor.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

I allow him this delusion. It serves my purposes. He is a man of influence, a respected figure in the community. His pronouncements carry weight. And I have learned to… steer those pronouncements in directions that benefit me.

He seeks my knowledge of herbs and remedies, of the… darker arts. He pretends to disapprove, to warn me against dabbling in the forbidden. But he always returns, seeking my assistance, desperate for answers he cannot find in his dusty tomes.

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze unwavering.)

I provide him with just enough to keep him intrigued, to keep him coming back. I offer him glimpses of power, of understanding, but always withhold the full truth. He is a moth drawn to a flame, and I am quite content to let him burn.

He believes he is controlling me, guiding me. He believes he is saving me from myself. The irony, of course, is that I am the one who is controlling *him*. I am the one who is using him.

(I offer a small, enigmatic smile.)

He is a useful pawn, Mr. Mather. A tedious, self-righteous pawn. But a pawn nonetheless. And I have no intention of allowing him to realize his true position. Let him continue to believe he is my shepherd. I assure you, I am quite capable of leading myself.)

(A long silence descends. I turn away, gazing into the flickering candlelight as if seeking solace within its depths. The question… touches a raw nerve. A carefully guarded secret.)
